entry.title: TOEFL_wordlist_06
entry.content:
TOEFL_wordlist

word_list_06

obsess

be preoccupied with something

the project seems to obsess him

atomic

of or relating to or comprising atoms

each atomic cluster is made up of neutrons and protons

finalize

make final

have talks but finalize your decision in June, not May

utter

express in speech

he uttered a snorting laugh

outrageously

in a very offensive manner

they behaved outrageously

mammal

a whale is a kind of mammal

inclination

an attitude of mind especially one that favors one alternative over others

she showed no inclination to go

particle

a tiny piece of anything

particle accelerators are cool

notify

inform of something

please notify us if the above is not correct

abortive

falling to accomplish an intended result

we had to abandon our abortive attempts

offset

a compensating equivalent

what expenses can you offset against tax?

catholic

a member of a Catholic church

they raised her(as) a Catholic

ambiguity

an expression whose meaning cannot be determined from its context

itâ€™s a work full of paradox and ambiguity

retrospective

an exhibition of a representative selection of artistâ€™s life work

Retrospectively,it seems as if they probably were negligent

overt

open and observable;not secret or hidden

there was little overt support for the project

strenuous

characterized by or performed with much energy or force

avoid strenuous exercise in the evening

puff

a short light gust of air

the magician vanished in a puff of smoke

instill

impart gradually

i aim to instill in them the pleasure of giving

avenge

take revenge for a perceived wrong

he promised to avenge his fatherâ€™s murder

meditate

reflect deeply on a subject

want to meditate and live in the moment?

gush

a sudden rapid flow

i heard a gush of water

predispose

make susceptible

stress can predispose people to heart attacks

languish

lose vigor,health,or flesh,as through grief

the housing market continues to languish

ravage

a destructive action

is it for you to ravage seas and land?

exodus

a journey by a large group to escape from a hostile environment

the great scientific exodus during WWII

consistency

the property of honlding together and retaining its shape

she has played with great consistency all season

exalt

praise,glorify,or honor

praise and exalt her many good points

prodigious

so great in size or force or extent as to elicit awe

this business generate cash in prodigious amounts

typify

embody the essential characteristics of or be a typical example of

these two building typify the rich extremes of local architecture

imitation

a copy that is represented as the original

a child learns to talk by imitation

compile

get or gather together

the book took 10 years to compile

propel

cause to move forward with force

these designs fuel demand and propel brand loyalty

hoe

a tool with a flat blade attached at right angles to a long handle

the ground is too hard to hoe

stride

a step in walking or running

he set off with a loping stride

tunnel

a passageway through or under something,usually underground(especially one for trains or cars)

the tunnel was blasted out of solid rock

friction

a state of conflict between persons

this layer of water reduces friction

wrinkle

a slight depression in the smoothness of a surface

his face was covered with wrinkle

plank

a stout length of sawn timber; made in a wide variety of sizes and used for many purposes

it was very strong,made of three solid planks of wood

eclecticism

making decisions on the basis of what seems best instead of following some single doctrine or style

eclecticism is the use of doctrines,methods,or styles from various sources

piracy

the act of plagiarizing;talking someoneâ€™s words or ideas as if they were your own

nobody thinks of this as piracy

deception

a misleading falsehood

he was jailed for two years for fraud and deception

subtle

faint and difficult to analyze

the truth is subtly different

dissenter

a person who dissents from some established policy

the party does not tolerate dissenters in its ranks

dictate

issue commands or orders for

thus the correct answer is dictate

aroma

any property detected by the olfactory system

they have a powerful aroma

niche

a position particularly well suited to the person who occupies it

he eventually found his niche in sports journalism

embody

represent in bodily form

for twenty-nine years,checkpoint charlie embodied the cold war

inviting

attractive and tempting
the water looks really inviting

entry.title: ç…§ç‰‡_01
TOEFL_wordlist_05
entry.content:
TOEFL_wordlist

word_list_03

envelop

enclose or enfold completely with or as if with a covering

that lovely,rich fragrant smell of the forest enveloped us

storage

the act of storing something

the table collapes for easy storage

proactive

controlling a situation by causing something to happen rather than waiting to respond to it after it happens

so we were being proactive and effective

posit

put firmly

most religions posit the existence of life after death

disguise

the act of concealing the identity of something by modifying its appearance

she disguised herself as a man so she could fight on the battlefield

embellish

add details to

but people to tend to embellish their avatars somewhat

weird

strikingly odd or unusual

sheâ€™s a realy weird girl

diverge

move or draw apart

opinions diverge greatly on this issue

infuriate

make furious

his view will infuriate mainstream historians

furious

marked by extreme and violent energy

a furious gunbattle ensured

repress

conceal or hide

he repressed a smile

thrust

the force used in pushing

she thrust her way into the crowd

casualty

an accident that causes someone to die

no casualty was reported yet

bestow

present

you also bestow love upon her or him

dissipate

live a life or pleasure,especially with respect to alcoholic consumption

donâ€™t dissipate your efforts

resolute

characterized by quickness and firmness

it is a resolute advocate of the anti-global movement

cranial

of or relating to the cranium which enclose the brain

the cranial capacity of Neandertals was about as large as ours

lineage

the descendants of one individual

they can trace their lineage back to the 18th century

balk

refuse to comply

even biology undergraduates may balk at animal experiments

irritate

excite to an abnormal condition,of chafe or inflame

their attitude irritates me

consolidate

make firm or secure;strengthen

what do they have to consolidate

intervening

occurring or falling between events or points in time

little had changed in the intervening years

corrosion

erosion by chemical action

zinc is used to protect other metals from corrosion

plump

make fat or plump

how plump,how beautiful she is

readily

without much difficulty

when she told them what she intended they readily consented

contamination

the state of being contaminated

some people are still suffering ill effects from the contamination of their water

pretentious

intended to attract notice and impress others

heâ€™s so pretentious

laser

barter

an equal exchange

they have been bartering wheat for cotton and timber

tenant

someone who pays rent to use land or a building or a car that is owned by someone else

the rent is a matter for negotiation between the landlord and the tenant

inscribe

carve,cut,or etch into a material or surface

his name is inscribe on the monument

flake

a small fragment of something broken off from the whole

like a flake in the storm

lease

a contract granting use or occupation of property during a specified time for a specified payment

he took up a 10-year lease on the house

courteous

exhibiting courtesy and politeness

he was a kind and courteous man

jeopardize

put at risk

the dispute could jeopardize the negotiations

detergent

a surface-active chemical widely used in industry and laundering

this detergent is good for getting stains out

imprint

a distinctive influence

she could see the imprint of her fingers on his pale face

bulk

the property resulting from being or relating to the greater in number of two parts

the bulk of the population lives in cities

spontaneity

the quality of being spontaneous and coming from natural feelings without constraint

he had the spontaneity of a child

mast

any sturdy upright pole

flags were flown at half mast on the day of his funeral

inanimate

appearing dead

a rock is an inanimate object

exhale

expel air

as the lungs exhale this waste,gas is expelled into the atmosphere

comply

act in accordance with someoneâ€™s rules,commands,or wishes

she must be made to comply with the rules

penetrate

pass into or through,often by overcoming resistance

X-rays can penetrate many objects

diversion

an activity that diverts or amuses or stimulates

the party will make a pleasant diversion

reserve

obtain or arrange in advance

iâ€™ll reserve at a table for five

exemplary

worthy of imitation

her behaviour was exemplary

leftover

a small part or portion that remains after the main part no longer exists

come over here and help me pack up the leftover food

conservationist

someone who works to protect the environment from destruction or pollution

todayâ€™s explorer must also be a conservationist

adhesive

a substance that unites or bonds surfaces together

he could wrap it in adhesive instead of putting it in a cast

entry.title: TOEFL_wordlist_04
entry.content:
TOEFL_wordlist

word_list_04

expertise

skillfulness by virtue of possessing special knowledge

we have the expertise to help you run your business

blend

an occurrence of thorough mixing

oil does not blend with water

fungus

mushroom

mushroom is an edible fungus

elasticity

the tendency of a body to return to its original shape after it has been stretched or compressed

daily facial exercises help to retain the skinâ€™s elasticity

moisture

wetness caused by water

the air is heavy with moisture

stout

a strong very dark heavy-bodied ale made from pale malt and roasted unmalted barley and caramel malt with hops

jacobs was a stout,florid man

assent

agreement with a statement or proposal to do something

he nodded assent

bizarre

conspicuously or grossly uncoventional or unusual

she dressed bizarrely

conceit

feelings of excessive pride

reyes emits confidence without conceit

husbandry

the practice of cultivating the land or raising stock

they depended on animal husbandry for their liveihood

abysmal

so deep as to be unmeasurable

the general standard of racing was abysmal

scorn

lack of respect accompanied by a feeling of intense dislike

the man looked at him with scorn

tranquil

free from disturbance by heavy waves

she led a tranquil life in the country

swoop

a very rapid raid

the hack poised in mid-air ready to swoop

punch

a blow with the fist

the punch sent him flying

mingle

get involved or mixed-up with

the flower mingle together to form a blaze of colour

interim

the time between one event,process,or period and another

please give me an interim receipt

laudable

worthy of high praise

one of emmaâ€™s less laudable characteristics was her jealousy

incur

receive a specified treatment

are they willing incur such a huge loss?

pretext

something serving to conceal plans

he left the party early on the pretext of having to work

replica

copy that is not the original

replica weapons are indistinguishable from the real thing

siege

the action of an armed force that surrounds a fortified place and isolates it while continuing to attack

after a long siege,the town was forced to yield

lunge

the act of moving forward suddenly

he lunged at me,grabbing me violently

crude

not processed or subjected to analysis

must you be quite so crude?

gibe

laugh at with contempt and derision

â€œplease donâ€™t gibe meâ€,lydia said

speckle

a small contrasting part of something

speckle the wall with tiny yellow spots

sardonic

disdainfully or ironically humorous

he was a big,sardonic man,who intimidated even the most self-confident students

nomadic

tending to travel and change settlement frequently

that led to a more normadic culture

confer

have a conference in order to talk something over

i will now confer a benefit on him

incessantly

with unflagging resolve

dee talked incessantly about herself

stadium

a large structure for open-air sports or entertainments

the stadium holds 75000 spectators

milieu

the environmental condition

they stayed,safe and happy,within their own social milleu

satiric

exposing human folly to ridicule

i donâ€™t quite into satiric literature

alchemist

Singed

would you rather be an alchemist or a chemist

untamed

in a natural state

therefore,the cyberspace is in many ways,an untamed frontier

diffusion

the spread of social institutions from one society to another

in december 1778,he proposed the plan"for the more general diffusion of knowledge"

stream

a natural body of running water flowing on or under the earth

there was a small stream at the end of the gardon

clipper

a fast sailing ship used in former times

this summer,clipper cut is preferred by many men

fray

a noisy fight

tempers began to fray as the two teams failed to score

prolific

intellectually productive

meyers is a dillgent and prolific worker

precede

be earlier in time

he gestured to alice to precede them from the room

listless

marked by low spirits;showing no enthusiasm

he was listless and pale and wouldnâ€™t eat much

stretch

make long or longer by pulling and stretching

we got out of the car and had a good stretch

groom

give a neat appearance to

the horses were exercised and groomed with the special care

dim

become or make darker

the light is too dim to read by

neuron

a cell that is specialized to conduct nerve impulses

each neuron seems to be more effective

marsh

low-lying wet land with grassy vegetation;usually is a transition zone between land and water

through the marsh grass,the birds are rising

eclipse

one celestial body obscures another

a total solar ecilpse is due to take place some time tomorrow

incentive

a positive motivational influence

extra credit is always a good incentive for students

puncture

be pierced or punctured

somebody helped me to mend the puncture

corrosive

a substance having the tendency to cause corrosion

seawater is corrosive

raven

eat greedily

the lions ravened the bodies

jot

a brief note

could you just jot his name on there?

prudent

careful and sensible

it is clearly prudent to take all precautions

ratify

apporve and express assent

the parliaments of australia and indonesia have yet to ratify the treaty

ideology

an orientation that characterizes the thinking of a group or nation

he attributed the partyâ€™s lack of success to an overemphasis on ideology and ideas

spur

incite or stimulate

let the cheers from the crowd spur you on

oyster

marine mollusks having a rough irregular shell; found on the sea bed mostly in coastal waters

He had two dozen oysters and enjoyed every one of them

entry.title: TOEFL_wordlist_03
entry.content:
TOEFL_wordlist

word_list_03

dwarf

a person who is markedly small

his figure is dwarfed by the huge red McDonaldâ€™s sign

muggy

hot or warm and wet

we may expect muggy weather when the rainy season begins

skyscraper

a very tall building with many stories

the skyscraper towers into the cloud

compliment

say something to someone that expresses praise

â€œyou were both wonderful!â€ so were you! we said,returning the compliment

repute

look on as or consider

he was a writer of repute

fauna

all the animal life in a particular region or period

so how is climate change affecting earthâ€™s flora and fauna

flora

all the plant life in a particular region or period

so how is climate change affecting earthâ€™s flora and fauna

mortality

the ratio of deaths in an area to the population of that area

the nationâ€™s infant mortality rate has reached a record low

predecessor

one who precedes you in time

the new govemor is an improvement on his predecessor

scrub

clean with hard rubbing

i started to scrub off the dirt

tout

show off

the magazines can tout this or that tiny

outrage

a feeling of righteous anger

the judgeâ€™s remarks caused public outrage

intrigue

a craty and involved a plot to achieve your ends

rumour and intrigue took over

connote

express or state indirectly

a lot of italics what does that connote to you?

persistent

never-ceasing

i had a persistent cough for over a month

secede

withdraw from an organization or communion

the seismic shock of a Soviet republic voting to secede showed that the Soviet Union was finished

bode

indivate by signs

her good habits bode well for her future

folkway

manner

mum said it is the local folkway and habitude

console

give moral or emotional strength to

i can console myself with the fact that iâ€™m not alone

overrun

too much production or more than expected

her lectures never overrun

turmoil

a violent disturbance

she lived through the turmoil of the French Revolution

amenable

disposed or willing to comply

they had three very amenable children

redundant

more than is needed,desired,or required

the picture has too much redundant detail

inverse

reversed in order or nature or effect

evil is the inverse of good

revive

give new life or energy to

the economy is beginning to revive

insulin

insulin enables the body to use and store sugar

cart

a heavy open wagon usually having two wheels and drawn by an animal

the horse is pulling a cart

pertinent

having precise or logical relevance to the matter at hand

she had asked some pertinent questions

rebellious

resisting control or authority

not bad for a rebellious high school dropout

barrel

a cylindrical container that holds liquids

oil prices fell to $9 a barrel

transition

the act of passing from one state or place to the next

lyric

the text of a popular song or musical-comedy number

he is a lyric poet

adorn

be beautiful to look at

several magnificent oil paintings adorn the walls

magnitude

huge

an operation of this magnitude is going to be difficult

utensil

an implement for pratical use

the spoon has the longest history as a dinner utensil

kennel

outbuilding that serves as a shelter for a dog

see my punishment:living in a kennel

internship

the position of a medical intern

the second new hurdle is the unpaid internship

starch

sugar and starch are broken down in the stomach

assimilation

the process of absorbing nutrients into the body after digestion

you 've got to do this gradual assimilation

detest

dislike intensely

i detest those who deceive me

gigantic

huge

the monument consists of a circle of gigantic stones

convention

a large formal assembly

he 's determined to speak at the Democratic Convention

diagonal

a staight line connecting any two vertices of a polygon that are not adjacent

the icon appears as two small squares that are in a diagonal

absenteeism

habitual absence from work

we predict this will dramatically reduce absenteeism in our schools and workplaces

digression

a message that departs from the main subject

let me just finish this digression

eternal

continuing forever

rome is truely the eternal city

sting

a mental pain or distress

some of the criticism has stung him

entry.title: TOEFL_wordlist_02
entry.content:
TOEFL_wordlist

word_list_02

dehydrate

remove water from

runners can dehydrate very quickly in this heat

sinuous

curved or curving in and out

i drove along sinuous mountain roads

uncanny

mysterious

i had an uncanny feeling i was being watched

sprinkle

distribute loosely

sprinkle the meat with salt and place in the pan

orthodox

custom

the orthodox answer is no

certitude

total certainty or greater certainty than circumstances warrant

we have this definite certitude that clark will be freed

hustle

a rapid active commotion

many people complained the hustle of life in modern society

engrave

carve cut

it is difficult to engrave in marble

homage

respect

as an homage,the script is named msgs.cgi

infatuate

crush

i think having idol is good think, but pay too much attention to infatuate them is not a good thing

exclusive

not divided or shared with others

some papers thought they had an exclusive

cynical

believing the worst of human nature and motives

times made us cynical

proclaim

declare formally

what better time to proclaim the good news

toxic

poisonate

many pesticides are highly toxic

rustproff

treated against rusting

stainless products are always popular because they are rustproff

vegetarian

eater of fruits and grains and nuts

are you vegetarian?

microbe

a minute life form

we have a microbe doing something different than llife as we know it

homestead

the home and adjacent ground occupied by a family

which problems in the countryside homestead management has?

canyon

a ravine formed by a river in an area with little rainfall

the canyon is hemmed in by towering walls of rock

portraiture

a word picture of a personâ€™s appearance and character

i am going to have my portraiture taken

alloy

a misture containing two or more metalic elements or metallic and nonmetallic elements usually fused together or dissolving into each other when molten

bronze is an alloy of copper and tin

microscopic

too small to be seen expect under a microscope

even microscopic organisms rely on microclimates for survival

verse

a piece of poetry

the poet fell in love with her and immortalized her in his verse

credential

certificate

accounts framework with secure credential store

pervasive

spreading or spread throughout

the most pervasive problem is less obvious:our own behaviour

lush

produced or growing in extreme abundance

the hills are covered in lush green vegetation

igneous

like fire

in geology,igneous rocks were once hot liquid

salient

outstanding

he summarized the salient points

shrivel

lose water

the plant shrivels and dies

syrup

a thick sweet sticky liquid

next,add the peanut butter and corn syrup

hemp

weeds

be careful not to kink hemp rope

dilate

become wider

the lungs dilate in breathing

flagellum

whip

it is a flagellum-the tail-like propeller found in single cells

intricate

complex

the plot of the novel is intricate and fascinating

tournament

a sporting competition

all the countryâ€™s leading players snubbed the tournament

ingredient

a component of a mixture or compound

what is the active ingredient in aspirin

terminal

end stop

he was eventually diagnosed as suffering from terminal cancer

inflammation

a response of body tissues to injury or irritation

the drug can cause inflammation of the liver

shield

protect

the gunman used the hostages as a human shield

versus

vs

it is france versus brazil in the final

entry.title: TOEFL_wordlist_01
entry.content:
TOEFL_wordlist

word_list_01

renaissance

the period of Enropean history at the close of the Middle Age

the history of renaissance is fantastic.

pluralism

deverse

this is an age of global pluralism.

vagrant

people who donâ€™t have job and home

vagrant donâ€™t have job,they have to beg for money.

grievous

make people sad

he survived in a grievous injury.

saucy

improperly bold

donâ€™t sassy me!

disproportionate

not proportionate

your time in study is disproportionate.

stumble

walk unsteadily

courage,brother,do not stumble.

obliterate

forget,erase,remove

they want to obliterate their crime.

affiliate

son compony

this is an affiliat of tencent.

rancorous

deep resent

yangliâ€™s talk show turned rancorous.

mediate

solve the dispute

he mediate between staff and management.

discharge

released

the dirty water was discharged into the river.

solicit

beg

they are soliciting money to treat his illness.

unravel

become underdone

he can unravel a knot that others wouldnâ€™t unravel.

unsubstantiated

canâ€™t supported by other evidence

their accuse is unsubstantiated.

stylized

using artistic forms and conventions to create effects; not natural or spontaneous

Beijing Opera portrays and narrates the plot and characters through stylized acting.

intrepid

bold,fearless

he is an intrepid boy

revere

respect

the movement revered craft as a form of art

secrete

generate and separate from cells or bodily fluids

the glands on its hind feet can secrete poisonous fluid

aria

an elaborate song for solo voice

this aria is fantastic

facilitate

make easier

the new airport will facilitate the development of tourism

feeble

lacking strength

the westâ€™s response was feeble

influx

the process of flowing in

that influx of cash compounds chinaâ€™s inflation troubles

receptacle

enlarged tip of a stem that bears the floral parts

learning doesnâ€™t consist in being an empty receptacle

kernel

a single whole grain of a cereal

want to become a kernel hacker?

segement

one of the parts into which something naturally divides

give me a segment of a orange to taste

nourish

provide with nourishment

she had three children to nourish

engulf

flow over or cover completely

hopelessness threatened to engulf him

bedrock

principles from which other truths can be derived

mutual trust is the bedrock of a relationship

unprecedented

having no precedent

we are now witnessing an unprecedented increase in violent crime

seep

leak

blood was beginning to seep through the bandages

patriarch

a man who is older and higher in rank than yourself

the little boy acted a patriarch role in the play

constrain

restrict

it turns out that great artists choose to constrain themselves all the time

sampling and estimation

why sampling?

  • examining every member of the population would not be economically efficient
  • we cannot possibly examine every member of the population

æŠ½æ ·çš„æ–¹æ³•

simple random sampling

a subset of larger population created in such a way that each element of the population has an equal probability of being selected to the subset

stratified random sampling

the population divided into subpopulations based on one or more classification criteria. then samples are pooled from these stratified subpopulations

survivorship bias

æ‹¿åˆ°æ ·æœ¬ç®—ä»€ä¹ˆ

estimator

formulas to compute the sample statistics to estimate the population parameter
an estimator is a random variable,so it has a sampling distribution

estimate

unbiasedness æ— åæ€§

è®¾Aâ€²=g(X1,X2,â€¦XN)A'= g(X_1,X_2, \dots X_N)Aâ€²=g(X1â€‹,X2â€‹,â€¦XNâ€‹)æ˜¯æœªçŸ¥å‚æ•°AAAçš„ä¸€ä¸ªä¼°è®¡é‡ï¼Œè‹¥Aâ€²A'Aâ€²æ»¡è¶³E(Aâ€²)=AE(A') = AE(Aâ€²)=Aï¼Œåˆ™ç§°Aâ€²A'Aâ€²ä¸ºAAAçš„æ— åä¼°è®¡é‡ã€‚

the calculated value of the sample statistic in a given sample, used as an estimate of the population parameter

interval estimate

calculating a range of values that brackets the unknown population parameter with some specified level of probability

normal distributions æ­£æ€åˆ†å¸ƒ

æ­£æ€åˆ†å¸ƒæ˜¯ç”¨æ¥åˆ»ç”»éšæœºå˜é‡å–å€¼æ¦‚ç‡å¯†åº¦çš„å‡½æ•°ã€‚æ¨ªåæ ‡æ˜¯éšæœºå˜é‡å¯èƒ½çš„å–å€¼ï¼Œçºµåæ ‡æ˜¯æ¦‚ç‡å¯†åº¦ï¼Œè€Œæ›²çº¿ä¸æ¨ªåæ ‡ä¸ŠæŸä¸€æ®µå˜é‡çš„å–å€¼æ‰€å›´æˆçš„é¢ç§¯ï¼Œç§¯ä¸ºéšæœºå˜é‡è½åœ¨è¿™ä¸€åŒºé—´çš„æ¦‚ç‡

the distribution of all the distinct possible values that the statistic can assume when computed from samples of the same size randomly drawn from the same population

ÏƒxË‰=Ïƒn\sigma_{\bar{x}} = \frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}}ÏƒxË‰â€‹=nâ€‹Ïƒâ€‹

A 100(1âˆ’Î±)100(1 - \alpha)%100(1âˆ’Î±) confidence interval for a parameter has the following structure:

pointÂ estimatÂ±reliabilityÂ factorâˆ—standardÂ errorpoint\ estimat \pm reliability\ factor * standard\ error pointÂ estimatÂ±reliabilityÂ factorâˆ—standardÂ error

  • $\alpha $ = significant level(æ˜¾è‘—æ€§æ°´å¹³),probability that the interval cannot covered the population parameter
  • 1-Î±\alphaÎ± = confident levelï¼ˆç½®ä¿¡åº¦ï¼‰ï¼Œprobability that the interval covered the population parameter
  • point estimate = a value of a sample statistic
  • reliablity factor = a number based on degree of confidence (1âˆ’Î±1-\alpha1âˆ’Î±) for the confidence interval
  • standard error = the standard deviation of the sample statistic

entry.title: Discounted Cash Flow Applications
entry.content:
Discounted Cash Flow Applications

Capital Budgeting (èµ„æœ¬é¢„ç®—)

The allocation of funds to relatively long-range projects or
investments. From the perspective of capital budgeting, a
company is a portfolio of projects and investments.

Capital Structure (èµ„æœ¬ç»“æ„)

The choice of long-term financing for the investments the
company wants to make

Working capital management (è¿è¥èµ„æœ¬ç®¡ç†)

The management of the companyâ€™s short-term assets and
short-term liabilities(å€ºåŠ¡)

Net Present Value (NPV, å‡€ç°å€¼)

The present value of its cash inflows(benefits) minus the
present value of its cash outflows(costs)

Calculation of NPV:

  • Identify all cash flows;
  • Determine the discount rate or opportunity cost Â®;
  • Find the present value of each cash flow;
  • Sum up all present value to get NPV

NPV=CF0+CF1(1+r)+CF2(1+r)2+â‹¯+CFn(1+r)nNPV = CF_0 +\frac{CF_1}{(1+r)} +\frac{CF_2}{(1+r)^2} + \dots +\frac{CF_n}{(1+r)^n}NPV=CF0â€‹+(1+r)CF1â€‹â€‹+(1+r)2CF2â€‹â€‹+â‹¯+(1+r)nCFnâ€‹â€‹

Apply the NPV rules:

  • If NPV > 0, undertake the project
  • If NPV â‰¤ 0, should not undertake the project;
  • For mutually exclusive projects (can only invest in one),
    choose the one with higher positive NPV.

Internal rate of return (IRR, å†…éƒ¨æ”¶ç›Šç‡) :

The discount rate that makes net present value equal to
zero

NPV=0=CF0+CF1(IRR)+CF2(IRR)2+â‹¯+CFn(IRR)n NPV = 0 = CF_0 +\frac{CF_1}{(IRR)} +\frac{CF_2}{(IRR)^2} + \dots +\frac{CF_n}{(IRR)^n}NPV=0=CF0â€‹+(IRR)CF1â€‹â€‹+(IRR)2CF2â€‹â€‹+â‹¯+(IRR)nCFnâ€‹â€‹

Apply the IRR rules:

IRR > opportunity cost of capital, undertake the project .

IRR â‰¤ opportunity cost of capital, should not undertake
the project

Problems with IRR rules

  • NPV and IRR rules give the same accept or reject decision
    when projects are independent, but may rank projects
    differently if projects are mutually exclusive when:

    • The size or scale of the projects differs;

    • The timing of the projectsâ€™ cash flows differs.

  • Stick to the NPV rule when NPVâ€™s and IRRâ€™s suggestions are
    conflict.

  • When the signs of cash flows change more than once, there
    can be more than one IRR.

Holding period return (æŒæœ‰æœŸæ”¶ç›Šç‡)

The return that an investor earns over a specified holding
period.

HPR=P1âˆ’P0+D1P0HPR = \frac{P_1-P_0+D_1}{P_0} HPR=P0â€‹P1â€‹âˆ’P0â€‹+D1â€‹â€‹

Example

Stock purchased nine months ago for $29 just paid a
dividend of $1.30 and is valued at $30.50. Calculate the
nine-month holding period return.

Answer:

HPR = (30.50 + 1.30 -29)/29 = 9.66%

Time-weighted return (TWR, æ—¶é—´åŠ æƒæ”¶ç›Šç‡)

The compound return that $1 initially invested in the
portfolio over a stated measurement period

Calculation of TWR:

  • Break the overall evaluation period into sub-periods based
    on the dates of significant cash inflows and outflows;
  • Calculate the HPRs for each sub-periods;
  • Link or compound HPRs to obtain an annual rate of return

TWR=[(EndÂ Value1BeginÂ Value1)(EndÂ Value2BeginÂ Value2)â€¦(EndÂ Value1BeginÂ Value1)]TWR = {[(\frac{End\ Value_1}{Begin\ Value_1})(\frac{End\ Value_2}{Begin\ Value_2}) \dots (\frac{End\ Value_1}{Begin\ Value_1})]} TWR=[(BeginÂ Value1â€‹EndÂ Value1â€‹â€‹)(BeginÂ Value2â€‹EndÂ Value2â€‹â€‹)â€¦(BeginÂ Value1â€‹EndÂ Value1â€‹â€‹)]

Steps to compute thetime-weighted return

Price the portfolio prior to any significant addition or
withdrawal of funds. Break the overall evaluation period
into sub-periods based on the dates of cash inflows and
outflows

Steps to compute the time-weighted return (Cont.)

  • Calculate the holding period return on the portfolio for
    each sub-period.
  • Compound each holding period return to obtain an annual
    rate of return for the measurement period (the timeweighted rate of return for the measurement period)

Money-weighted return (MWR, è´§å¸åŠ æƒæ”¶ç›Šç‡)

MWR accounts for the timing and amount of all cash flows
into and out of the portfolio

  • If more funds to invest at an unfavorable time, MWR will
    tend to be depressed;
  • If more funds to invest at a favorable time, MWR will tend
    to be elevated

Calculation of MWR:

similar to IRR

CF0+CF1(1+MWR)+â‹¯+CFn(1+MWR)n=0 CF_0 +\frac{CF_1}{(1+MWR)} + \dots +\frac{CF_n}{(1+MWR)^n = 0}CF0â€‹+(1+MWR)CF1â€‹â€‹+â‹¯+(1+MWR)n=0CFnâ€‹â€‹

Steps to compute the money-weighted return

  • Identify the cash inflows and cash outflows by time
    and then group the net cash flows.
  • Find the money-weighted return based on the rule of
    NPV equal to zero.

TWR vs. MWR

Time weighted return:

  • Not affected by cash withdrawals or additions;
  • Periods can be any length between significant cash flows

Money weighted return

  • Assign more weights to the return of larger cash flows;
  • Affected by cash withdrawals or additions;
  • Periods must be equal length

  • Use shortest period with no significant cash flows

Money Market Yields

###ã€€Money Market (è´§å¸å¸‚åœº)
The market for short-term debt instruments (one-year
maturity or less)

Pure Discount Instruments (çº¯è´´ç°å·¥å…·)

The financial instruments that pay interest as the difference
between the amount borrowed and the amount paid
back(e.g., US T-bill)

Face Value (é¢å€¼)

The amount the issuer promises to pay back to the
investors if it is held at maturity

Discount (æŠ˜æ‰£)

The difference between the face value and the purchase
price.

Holding period yield (HPY)

HPY = (Ending Value/Beginning Value) - 1

Bank discount yield (BDY)

BDY = (Discount/Face Value) Ã— (360/Days to maturity)

Discount rate, simple interest, 360-day annualized

Money Market Yield (MMY)

MMY = (Discount/Price) Ã— (360/Days to maturity)

Add-on rate, simple interest, 360-day annualized

Bond Equivalent Yield (BEY, å€ºåˆ¸ç­‰ä»·æ”¶ç›Šç‡)

BEY = (Discount/Price) Ã— (365/Days to maturity)

Add-on rate, simple interest, 365-day annualized;

Only for money market, not available for capital market

Effective annual yield (EAY, æœ‰æ•ˆå¹´åˆ©ç‡)

EAY=(1+HPY)365/Daysâˆ’1EAY = (1+HPY)^{365/Days}-1EAY=(1+HPY)365/Daysâˆ’1

Add-on rate, compound interest, 365-day annualized

entry.title: Time Value of Money
entry.content:
Time Value of Money è´§å¸æ—¶é—´ä»·å€¼

Time value of money(è´§å¸æ—¶é—´ä»·å€¼)

TVM is the building block of finance theories
It is important to master TVM basics to have comprehensive
insight of other CFA subjects

Time value of money (è´§å¸æ—¶é—´ä»·å€¼)

Money available at the present time is worth more than the
same amount in the future due to its potential earning
capacity.

  • Provided money can earn interest, any amount of money is
    worth more the sooner it is received

  • It concerns equivalence relationships between cash flows
    occurring on different dates.

Cash flow additivity principle

The amounts of money can only be added on if they are
indexed at the same point in time

Interest Rate

Interpretations of Interest Rate (åˆ©ç‡)

Required rate of return (è¦æ±‚æ”¶ç›Šç‡)

minimum rate of return an investor must receive in order to accept the
investment.

Discounted rate (æŠ˜ç°ç‡)

the rate at which we discount the future amounts to find their value today.

Opportunity cost (æœºä¼šæˆæœ¬ï¼‰

the value that investors forgo by choosing a particular course of action.

Example

Selmer Jones has just inherited some money and wants to set
some of it aside for a vacation in Hawaii one year from today.
His bank will pay him 5% interest on any funds he deposits. In
order to determine how much of the money must be set aside
and held for the trip, he should use the 5% as a:

A. required rate of return

B. discount rate

C. opportunity cost

Answer: B
He needs to figure out how much the trip will cost in one year,
and use the 5% as a discounted rate to convert the future cost
to a present value. Thus, in this context the rate is best viewed
as a discount rate.

components of interest rate

real risk-free interest rate

single-period interest rate for risk-free security without inflation expected

inflation premiun(é€šè´§è†¨èƒ€æº¢ä»·)

compensating investors for expected inflation risk

Nominalinterestrate(åä¹‰åˆ©ç‡)=Realriskâˆ’freeinterestrate+Inflationpremium+Defaultriskpremium+Liquiditypremium+MaturitypremiumNominal interest rate (åä¹‰åˆ©ç‡) = Real risk-free interest rate+ Inflation premium+ Default risk premium+ Liquidity premium+ Maturity premiumNominalinterestrate(åä¹‰åˆ©ç‡)=Realriskâˆ’freeinterestrate+Inflationpremium+Defaultriskpremium+Liquiditypremium+Maturitypremium

risk premium

default risk premium(è¿çº¦é£é™©æº¢ä»·)

compensating investors for the possibility that the borrower will fail to
make the promised payments in time and in full amount.

liquidity premium(æµåŠ¨æ€§é£é™©æº¢ä»·)

compensating investors for the risk of loss relative to an investmentâ€™s fair value if the investment needs to be converted to cash
quickly

maturity premium(åˆ°æœŸé£é™©æº¢ä»·)

compensating investors for the increased sensitivity of the market value of debt to a change in market interest rates as maturity is
extended

riskpremium=defaultriskpremium+liquiditypremium+maturitypremiumrisk premium = default risk premium + liquidity premium + maturity premiumriskpremium=defaultriskpremium+liquiditypremium+maturitypremium

interest rate

simple interest(å•åˆ©)

The annual interest rate times the principal

compounding interest(å¤åˆ©)

The interest earned on interest is counted in

Example

If the annual interest rate is 10% and the principal is $1000,
what is the interest earned in 2 years under simple interest
and compounding interest?

Answer:

Under simple interest:Interest earned = $1000 Ã— 10% Ã— 2 = $200
Under compounding interest:
Interest earned = $1000 Ã— (1+10%) Ã—(1+10%) - $1000 = $210

Stated annual interest rate/Quoted interest rate (rsr_srsâ€‹)

The annual interest rate that does not account for compounding within the year

Compounding frequency (m, å¤åˆ©é¢‘æ¬¡)

The number of compounding periods per year

Continuous compounding:

the number of compounding periods per year becomes infinite.

Periodic interest rate (rsm\frac{r_s}{m}mrsâ€‹â€‹, æœŸé—´åˆ©ç‡)

Stated annual rate divided by the compounding frequency

Stated annual rate divided by the compounding frequency

The rate by which a unit of currency will grow in a year with
interest on interest included.

EAR=1+Periodicinterestrateâˆ’1=(1+rsm)mâˆ’1EAR = 1 +Periodic interest rate -1 = (1 + \frac{r_s}{m})^m -1EAR=1+Periodicinterestrateâˆ’1=(1+mrsâ€‹â€‹)mâˆ’1

For continuous compounding:

EAR=esrâˆ’1EAR=e^r_s -1EAR=esrâ€‹âˆ’1

because

limâ¡nâ†’âˆ(1+1n)n=e\lim_{n\rightarrow \infty}{(1+\frac{1}{n})^n} = enâ†’âˆlimâ€‹(1+n1â€‹)n=e

example

If the stated annual rate is 8%, compute the effective annual
rate with quarterly compounding

Answer

EAR=(1+8%/4)4â€“1=1.0824â€“1=8.24%EAR = (1 + 8\%/4)^4 â€“ 1 = 1.0824 â€“ 1 = 8.24\% EAR=(1+8%/4)4â€“1=1.0824â€“1=8.24%

annualy compounded å¹´å¤åˆ©

semi -annually compounded åŠå¹´å¤åˆ©â€”â€”å€ºåˆ¸

quatterly compounded å­£åº¦å¤åˆ©â€”â€”æ´»æœŸ

monthly componded æœˆå¤åˆ©â€”â€”è´·æ¬¾

continuously è¿ç»­å¤åˆ©â€”â€”è¡ç”Ÿå“

Relationships between PV and FV (Cont.)

Present value (PV, ç°å€¼)

the value of an initial investment

Future value (FV, ç»ˆå€¼)

the value of an initial investment would be worth n periods from today

Present value and future value are equivalent measures
separated in time

FV=PV(1+r)nFV = PV (1+r)^n FV=PV(1+r)n

or

PV=FV(1+r)nPV=\frac{FV}{(1+r)^n}PV=(1+r)nFVâ€‹

where: r = periodic rate, n = number of periods

Relationships between PV and FV (Cont.)

  • For a given interest rate, the FV increases with the number
    of periods.
  • For a given number of periods, the FV increases with the
    interest rate.
  • For a given interest rate, the farther in the future the
    amount to be received, the smaller that amountâ€™s PV.
  • Holding time constant, the larger the interest rate, the
    smaller the PV of a future amount.

Example

Suppose a $10,000 investment and a stated annual interest
rate of 8%, compute the future value with monthly
compounding and continuous compounding

Answer

For monthly compounding:

FVN=PVâˆ—(1+rsm)m=10000âˆ—(1+0.0812)12FV_N = PV * (1+\frac{r_s}{m})^m = 10000 * (1+\frac{0.08}{12})^{12} FVNâ€‹=PVâˆ—(1+mrsâ€‹â€‹)m=10000âˆ—(1+120.08â€‹)12

For continuous compounding:

FV=PVâˆ—ers=10000âˆ—e0.08=10832.87FV = PV*e^{r_s} = 10000*e^{0.08}=10832.87FV=PVâˆ—ersâ€‹=10000âˆ—e0.08=10832.87

Annuity (å¹´é‡‘)

A finite set of constant sequential cash flows

Ordinary annuity (æ™®é€šå¹´é‡‘)

all constant cash flows
occurring at the end of each period\

Annuity due (æœŸåˆå¹´é‡‘)

all constant cash flows occurring
at the beginning of each period

Perpetuity (æ°¸ç»­å¹´é‡‘)

A set of constant never-ending sequential cash flows
occurring at the end of each period
